resources.string:
One of the golden rules on the Internet is to
never share personal information with anyone.
Despite that, cyber criminals can still take your
information without you knowing. 

Cyber Attack Learning contains information
about identifying and protection against cyber
attacks. 

Click on the tab bar on the top of the screen to
learn more about three types of cyber attacks.

Malware, short for malicious software, is a type 
of program or code that intentionally harms 
a computer to disrupt its normal operations and/or functionality. 

There are different types of malware: 
- Adware 
- Ransomware 
- Spyware 
- Rootkit 
- Trojan Horse 
- Virus 
- Worm 
- Keyloggers 
- Bots 

To protect yourself against malware, you can: 
- Download antimalware software 
- Download apps or files only from trusted websites 
- Check developer descriptions 
- Do not click on unverified links 
- Keep operating system and apps updated. 

Sources:
- https://thecyphere.com/blog/types-of-malware/

Computer viruses are a type of malware whose
purpose is to destroy data by attaching itself to
multiple files, just like an actual, physical virus. Hackers like to create some sort of
disruption, thinking of it like some funny prank. But others do it to deliberately cause
 harm to other people. Through downloading files from the internet, using packaged/unpatched software,pen drives, clicking on email attachments or USBs and hard drives, the computer gets a program or file with the virus. When you open a file or run a program with it, the host computer gets infected. Then the virus starts spreading itself to other parts of the computer or to other computers. 

There are different types of viruses: 
- Boot sector: This type of virus destroys a computer through its core. It attaches itself on floppy disks, USB drives, or emails, and once activated, it heads straight to the master boot record and disrupts the computer’s startup process. 
- Direct Action: 
- Macro: 
- Multipartite: 
- Overwrite virus: 
- Polymorphic: 
- Resident: 
- Spacefiller: 

To protect yourself against viruses, you can: 
- Back files up 
- Do a virus scan 
- Don’t click on suspicious links or pop-ups 
- Installing virus detection or antivirus software 
- Using a firewall 

Sources: 
- https://www.buddycompany.com/post/types-of-computer-virus 
- https://hightouchtechnologies.com/9-common-types-of-computer-viruses/ 
- https://logixconsulting.com/2021/06/15/what-is-a-direct-action-computer-virus/ 
- https://www.malwarebytes.com/macro-virus 
- https://www.kyoceradocumentsolutions.com/in/en/about-us/blog/8-common-types-of-computer-viruses.html 
- https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/definition/polymorphic-virus 
- https://allaboutcookies.org/what-is-a-computer-virus 
- https://www.mcafee.com/learn/computer-viruses/

Scams are well-known to be deceptive
practices where someone tricks you into
thinking that what they’re offering has no
catch at all. 

The same thing goes with Internet scams. Internet scams can come in all forms. 

There is a different type of scam called phishing, and it comes in many forms: 
- Angler Phishing 
- Clone Phishing 
- Email Phishing and Sextortion 
- Pharming 
- Pop-up Phishing 
- Search Engine Phishing 
- Smishing and Vishing 
- Spear Phishing 
- Whaling 

Sources:
- https://www.itgovernance.eu/blog/en/the-5-most-common-types-of-phishing-attack 
- https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/what-is/phishing/types-of-phishing.html 
- https://www.bluevoyant.com/knowledge-center/8-phishing-types-and-how-to-prevent-them 
- https://www.upguard.com/blog/types-of-phishing-attacks
People lost $10 billion to scams\nin 2023, according to the FTC.
In 1986, the very first computer virus, a\nboot sector virus called Brain, was made.
250,000 computer viruses are\nregistered every single day of the year.
67% of ransomware attempts in the\nUS involved some form of phishing.
Cyber criminals have started using\nAI to manipulate victims better.
The most common malware file type\nreceived in 2022 were exe files.
One of the youngest hackers in the US was\nJonathan James, who hacked NASA.
Two-factor authentication alarms users of\nother devices trying to get in the account.
Products online with too-good-to-be-true\nprices are usually too good to be true.
Thoroughly reading mail you receive from\nbusinesses may prevent scams or malware.
A quiz where you fill the blanks of a sentence and\ntry to get the correct answer! Contains a total of \n10 questions with a 15-question pool.
A true or false quiz filled with questions about \nmalware, viruses, and scams! Contains a total of \n10 questions with a 15-question pool.
Spyware is a type of malware.
Spacefillers are rare viruses because it has a different encryption key each time it replicates.
Resident viruses hide in a computer’s memory.
Viruses can be avoided by using bynewalls.
Backing files up is useless because they can be overwritten anyway.
